title: MongoBleed: MongoDB Memory Leak Under Active Exploitation (CISA KEV)

timeline.event: MongoDB Security Engineering team identifies the vulnerability
MongoDB releases security advisory and patches
Public proof-of-concept exploit published on GitHub
Active exploitation begins in the wild
CISA adds CVE-2025-14847 to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
CISA deadline for federal agencies to patch

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical HeartBleed-like vulnerability has been discovered in MongoDB database - dubbed MongoBleed. This flaw allows attackers to steal sensitive data (passwords, API keys, session tokens) from MongoDB server memory without authentication. The vulnerability stems from a bug in MongoDB's zlib compression feature.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: All organizations running self-hosted MongoDB are at risk. According to Wiz research, 42% of cloud environments have vulnerable MongoDB instances. Censys data shows 87,000+ vulnerable MongoDB servers exposed to the internet. MongoDB Atlas users have been automatically patched and are safe.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attacker locates internet-exposed MongoDB server (port 27017). Step 2: Sends specially crafted OP_COMPRESSED messages. Step 3: Leaks random data chunks from MongoDB server memory. Step 4: Establishes thousands of connections to harvest more data. Step 5: Extracts passwords, API keys, and session tokens. Step 6: Uses stolen credentials for unauthorized system access.
what_you_should_do: If immediate patching is not possible, disable zlib compression
Do not expose MongoDB to the internet - protect with firewall
Review MongoDB logs for abnormal connection patterns
Assume breach and rotate all credentials
If using MongoDB Atlas, no action needed - automatically patched
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: MongoDB is the world's most popular NoSQL database, powering critical applications. Attackers can extract sensitive data without authentication. It is already being actively exploited in the wild and CISA has added it to the mandatory patch list. Public PoC exploit is available - anyone can use it.

tactics.description: Sensitive data harvested through memory leak exploitation
Passwords and API keys extracted from server memory
Stolen data exfiltrated to attacker-controlled servers

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor MongoDB logs for abnormal pre-authentication connections and missing client metadata. The exploit does not send client metadata unlike legitimate MongoDB drivers.

log_sources.description: Connection events, authentication attempts, and crash logs
High-volume connection attempts to MongoDB port

what_to_look_for.description: Normal MongoDB drivers always send client metadata. The exploit does not.
what_to_look_for.log_field: Connections without corresponding Event ID 51800 metadata

what_to_look_for.description: 50,000-100,000+ connection attempts per minute from single IP
what_to_look_for.log_field: connections per minute from single IP > 1000

what_to_look_for.description: Many connections opened and closed before authentication completes
what_to_look_for.log_field: High connection count with zero successful auth

what_to_look_for.description: Unexpected MongoDB service crashes may indicate exploitation attempts

immediate_actions.description: Determine which version you are running - is it vulnerable?
If running a vulnerable version, upgrade IMMEDIATELY
If immediate patching is not possible, disable zlib compression
Do not expose MongoDB to the internet, allow only trusted IPs
Check for abnormal connection patterns in the last 30 days
Assume breach and rotate all database credentials
